verses.text: If, in the land that the LORD your God is giving you to possess, someone is found lying in a field, murdered, and it is unknown who killed him,
verses.comment: God addresses justice and communal responsibility, foundational for later moral teachings.

verses.text: then your elders and judges must go out and measure the distance from the body to the nearby towns.
verses.comment: Local leadership bears responsibility, prefiguring need for order and discernment.

verses.text: The elders of the town nearest to the body shall take a young cow that has never been worked or worn a yoke.
verses.comment: The unworked heifer symbolizes innocence and ritual purity, echoing sacrificial imagery for forgiveness.

verses.text: They shall bring the cow down to a valley with flowing water, where it has not been plowed or sown, and break the cow's neck there in the valley.
verses.comment: Purification over water and breaking the neck suggest atonement. Water often represents cleansing in Scripture (John 3:5).

verses.text: Then the priests, the descendants of Levi, shall come forward, because the LORD your God has chosen them to minister and to bless in his name, and by their word every dispute and case of assault shall be settled.
verses.comment: The priesthood mediates reconciliation and blessing; foreshadows mediatory roles for ordained ministers (Heb. 7:23-25).

verses.text: All the elders of the town nearest to the slain man shall wash their hands over the cow whose neck was broken in the valley.
verses.comment: Washing hands symbolizes innocence; parallels Pilate's gesture in the Passion account, highlighting need for true purity.

verses.text: And they shall declare, 'Our hands did not shed this blood, nor did our eyes see it done.'
verses.comment: A communal profession of innocence, anticipating liturgical confession and prayer for forgiveness.

verses.text: 'Accept atonement, O LORD, for your people Israel, whom you have redeemed, and do not hold the guilt of innocent blood among your people.' Thus they shall purge the guilt of blood from among them.
verses.comment: Intercessory prayer for atonement, foreshadows the necessity of sacrificial redemption fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: So you shall remove the guilt of innocent blood from among you, by doing what is right in the sight of the LORD.
verses.comment: Moral cleanliness is linked with ritual; hints at the deep connection between justice, mercy, and liturgy.

verses.text: When you go out to battle against your enemies, and the LORD your God delivers them into your hands and you take them captive,
verses.comment: Victory comes from God; reminds readers of dependence on divine providence, not mere human effort.

verses.text: and you see among the captives a beautiful woman and desire her, you may take her for yourself as a wife.
verses.comment: The Law provides for marriage rather than mere exploitation; protection of dignity even in conquest foreshadows Christ's restoration of all through union.

verses.text: You must bring her into your house, shave her head, trim her nails,
verses.comment: Initiation rites signal transition from her former life; echoes themes of conversion and cleansing.

verses.text: take off the clothes she was wearing when captured, remain in your house, and mourn her father and mother for a full month. Then you may go to her and be her husband, and she shall be your wife.
verses.comment: Respect for the woman’s grief shows the Law’s concern for human dignity before marriage; anticipates Christ’s compassion for all, regardless of background.

verses.text: But if you are not pleased with her, you shall let her go wherever she desires. You must not sell her for money or treat her as a slave, because you have humbled her.
verses.comment: The Law protects the vulnerable, showcasing principles of justice and mercy that define Christian ethics.

verses.text: If a man has two wives, one loved and the other unloved, and both have borne him sons, but the firstborn is from the unloved wife,
verses.comment: The Law addresses issues from imperfect family situations yet upholds justice, foreshadowing the New Testament’s insistence on impartial love.

verses.text: when dividing his inheritance among his sons, he may not choose the son of the loved wife over the firstborn of the unloved wife.
verses.comment: God’s justice defends the rights of the firstborn regardless of favoritism, pointing toward the impartiality of grace.

verses.text: He must recognize the firstborn, son of the unloved wife, by giving him a double portion of all he has, for he is the first to show his father's strength; the right of the firstborn belongs to him.
verses.comment: Firstborn rights again echoed; ultimately fulfilled when Christ, ‘firstborn’ of the dead, receives the fullness of inheritance (Col. 1:18).

verses.text: If a man has a stubborn and rebellious son who will not obey his father or mother, even when disciplined,
verses.comment: Family order is crucial. Obedience to parents is later insisted upon in apostolic teaching (Eph. 6:1).

verses.text: his father and mother shall take hold of him and bring him out to the elders at the gate of his town.
verses.comment: Parents and community share responsibility for discipline; gates are places of judgment, emphasizing communal justice.

verses.text: They shall say to the elders, 'This son of ours is stubborn and rebellious. He will not obey us. He is a glutton and a drunkard.'
verses.comment: Sinful behaviors named echo the prodigal son parable, showing the Law’s call for conversion and restoration.

verses.text: Then all the men of his town shall stone him to death. So you shall purge the evil from among you, and all Israel will hear and be afraid.
verses.comment: Severe discipline for community holiness; in the New Testament discipline becomes spiritual, urging repentance not vengeance.

verses.text: If a man is guilty of a capital offense and is executed, and you hang him on a tree,
verses.comment: Hanging points prophetically to Christ’s crucifixion, who bore the curse for sinners; see also Galatians 3:13.

verses.text: his body shall not remain on the tree overnight, but you must bury him that same day, for anyone hung on a tree is cursed by God. You must not defile your land that the LORD your God is giving you as an inheritance.
verses.comment: Burial and removing the curse fulfillment in Christ; He is buried swiftly after the crucifixion (John 19:38-42), showing God’s plan even in judgment.
